properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Northwesterly wind gusts of 90 to 110 kilometres per hour will occur beginning Tuesday morning. Winds will diminish late Tuesday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T19:50:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T03:51:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3597512514.2020
Area: Kangiqsujuaq - Raglan Lake, Quaqtaq, Kangirsuk, Aupaluk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong to high northwesterly winds will produce blizzard conditions today. Weather conditions will improve gradually at the end of the day. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to give blowing snow with widespread visibilities reduced to 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T03:59:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T17:39:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4085661315.2020
Area: Ivujivik, Kangiqsujuaq - Raglan Lake, Quaqtaq, Kangirsuk, Kangiqsualujjuaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A moisture laden frontal system over the BC south coast has produced heavy rain over West Vancouver Island. Stations have received over 70 mm of rain last night. Additional rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm can be expected this morning. The rain will taper off late this morning as the system moves eastward, ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T23:54:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T12:53:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1160975230.2020
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Light snow will continue through much of the day morning across the Fort Nelson region. Later this afternoon, an advancing impulse will lead to increased snowfall rates. 10 to 15 cm of snow can be expected before snow tapers off overnight. The swath of higher snowfall accumulations are expected to fall south of the city of Fort Nelson itself, impacting Highway 97, near Prophet River. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T04:08:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T12:09:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1311469208.2020
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind gusts near 100 km/h are forecast to develop this afternoon and are expected to last into Wednesday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow is forecast to begin this afternoon over northwestern Alberta and spread eastwards throughout the evening and overnight. Snow will end Wednesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A frontal system carrying sub-tropical moisture has moved onto the south coast, bringing heavy rain to the lower mainland and parts of Vancouver Island. Total rainfall amounts of 40 to 60 mm are expected over the lower mainland, Howe Sound and Whistler as well as near Qualicum Beach on east Vancouver Island. The rain will taper off to a few showers this afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-04T04:53:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T12:54:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0465278456.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, Whistler, Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total Snowfall Amounts: 5 to 10 cm with up to 20 cm possible in some areas. Time frame: overnight tonight into Wednesday morning. Locations: Parts of central, southern, eastern, and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Environment Canada Meteorologists are tracking a developing low pressure system forecast to track across the Avalon Peninsula tonight. The forecast track of this system has been trending westward and forecast guidance is coming into agreement on potential for a significant snowfall overnight tonight in to Wednesday morning combined with strong northwesterly winds. The details are currently being worked on and warnings might be required for some areas in subsequent forecasts later today. The public should prepare for accumulating snow and winter driving conditions for the morning commute on Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-04T06:21:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T14:22:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3826637020.2020
